intro: Geum × sanguineum, commonly known as the bloodtwig dogwood, is a deciduous shrub native to eastern North America. It is characterized by its striking red stems that remain visible throughout the winter, adding visual interest to the landscape. The plant produces clusters of small, white to pinkish flowers in the spring, which are followed by red berries in the fall. Its leaves are typically ovate to elliptic, with serrated edges and a dark green upper surface. Geum × sanguineum thrives in partial to full shade and moist, well-drained soil, making it a popular choice for woodland gardens.
